Hi Mike, Mike and Glenn.
This is my humble take:
1. Application is far mor=
e that just a component. My definition includes business goals and the like=
, so I won't enter there.

2. A system includes not only the components but=
 the inter-relationships, interfaces and externally visible properties. As =
I once stated in this forum, a client is a role, and can be played by one c=
omponent inside a system A, and by another system B consuming services on S=
ystem A. So we can have a system of systems, where their components can be =
playing different roles, one of them being a client.

3. That clarified, RE=
ST is an architectural style that defines component roles and rules of enga=
gement to achieve a set of quality properties. Theory says that one compone=
nt not playing the role or not following the rules, may affect the property=
 quality achievement. Clear?

4. Now, in any modern architecture developmen=
t, we architects should not focus only in functional requirements, but in q=
uality properties too. That means making decisions about how things are goi=
ng to work, stating policies and making sure those policies are enforced. F=
ollowing this line of thinking, implementing an architectural conception th=
at follows REST style, but that does not enforce the rules or does not even=
 detect a rule is being broken (a governance problem), I should say it is a=
 weak implementation. And if we are not in control of all components (other=
 people creating their services and clients) then we may not achieve the qu=
ality properties after all.

5. But all that is not REST fault, and shouldn=
't care less. That is the work of the architect, designers and developers a=
nd other stakeholders. REST is not an out-of-the-box solution you get when =
you install a framework and use it. A framework may help, but the actual su=
ccess of delivering business value comes from the work of all people. You w=
ill get nowhere if a bunch of your developers keep not following the rules.=
 If an external "client" enters the system, and is not playing the rules, m=
ay affect the quality properties, and sure it will suffer itself from that,=
 when the server changes the uri namespace or the flow, then it becomes a p=
roblem of the spoiled client. 

My two cents.

William Martinez Pomares
